Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Air Stream Purification Using Electron Sources from Carbon Nanotube Emitters
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop a carbon nanotube based filament that acts as an electron emitter. The carbon nanotube filament will be applied to air handling systems for the purpose of reducing volatile organic compounds and biological contaminants. When a voltage is applied to the carbon nanotube filament it emits an electron beam. Contaminants that are within the reaction chamber react with electrons and decompose into less toxic materials.

The broader/commercial impact of the project will be the development of an improved electron beam source that requires lower voltage and does not produce x-ray radiation. The technology addresses both chemical and biological contaminants in air, which will make it an attractive solution with marketing potential. The device will be scalable from larger, commercial air handling systems to smaller-scale office and in-home devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Awardee: 4WIND SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING, LLC

Award Number: 1013489

 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will address the problem of increasing global air pollution due to factors such as the rising number of coal-fired power plants and the growth in the chemicals and fertilizers industry. Government regulations have mandated industries to lower noxious emissions as a result of this problem. Electron beam irradiation is a very effective way of converting air pollutants into more benign byproducts instead of merely trapping them. However, present day e-beam systems are power inefficient, costly, and generate harmful X-rays. During Phase I of this project we introduced a novel, power efficient electron source composed of carbon nanotube field emitters. As compared to the present system, our electron source also features a highly electron transparent window which allows us to transmit electron beams from vacuum into the polluted air stream at low accelerating voltages, making the system free of hard X-rays. In Phase II we will scale up the electron source and characterize it, as well as design and manufacture a full scale prototype for testing at customer sites. We anticipate that this new air purification system will lead to a 7.5X increase in the performance to cost ratio as compared to current industrial systems.

 

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs), the enabling technology in our e-beam system, have been heavily researched among various scientific disciplines because of their outstanding mechanical, thermal, and electrical properties. From a technological standpoint, their potential applications are far reaching beyond e-beam irradiation. In particular CNT field electron emitters are attractive for vacuum electron device applications, such as amplifiers, displays, and cathodoluminescent lighting. The project would result in an enhanced scientific and technological understanding of these CNT field emitters.

Our proposed air purification equipment would have an immediate societal impact in addressing industrial air pollution. It would eventually have a broader impact in commercial and residential spaces as well, where air pollution has resulted in increased cases of diseases and respiratory infections. Additionally, air quality is always a concern in hospitals and airplane cabins. Unlike previous technology the proposed system will not generate X-rays and will be cheaper and smaller, making it a very practical solution for homes, businesses, hospitals, and airplane cabins. Air pollution aside, e-beam irradiation is useful for surface treatment as well, including food sterilization, medical sterilization, and curing paint. Thus the potential societal and commercial impact of this NSF project could be tremendous.


Last Modified: 10/13/2011
Modified by: Cattien V Nguyen
